content: i heard natives are asking for our own veterans day. not sure what i think. i'm native, and a navy retiree. and i know as a racial group, we have a much higher percentage for people joining and serving in the military than another other race. and yet, when i watch the parades, etc i never see any other natives. thoughts?
reply: i heard natives are asking for our own veterans day. not sure what i think. i'm native, and a navy retiree. and i know as a racial group, we have a much higher percentage for people joining and serving in the military than another other race. and yet, when i watch the parades, etc i never see any other natives. thoughts?
title: native american veterans

content: Interesting question..... What percentage of "Native American" must a person be, in order to be proud of their heritage? I know I can't get an Indian Card, but I DO have Indiginous personages in my roots (with family trees). I am proud of all my relatives, does that count?? Also, I think we need to be cautious when we start adding "holidays" to the calender. Califirnia is seeking to add Harvey Milk's Birthday as a holiday in honor of "gay politicians" with the justification that we have a president's day, and, a Martin Luther King Day. And all because of the popularity of a Hollywood movie!! Instead of creating another holiday, I would think that encouraging the existing Native American Vets to take an active part in the Memorial Day Observations and Veteran's Day festivities would be a smarter way to go. Just my opinion, tho......

content: I'd have no problem with a Holiday to the Continent's First Residents... Maybe honoring Squanto's selfless efforts to help the Pilgrims, Pocahontas's saving of John Smith, and Sacajawea's help in getting the Shoshonee to aid the Louis and Clark expedition...or just in general. I don't know a good specific day, though many Indians put great value on June 21st, since most revere the Sun, and that is its longest day... Wouldn't bother me none - cuz it's my birthday - - Indians/Native Americans have had a pretty rough go of it for the last 300 years at the hands of European-types. I'd much prefer to see a little honor shown their way-ahey Wandering and Wondering
reply: I'd have no problem with a Holiday to the Continent's First Residents... Maybe honoring Squanto's selfless efforts to help the Pilgrims, Pocahontas's saving of John Smith, and Sacajawea's help in getting the Shoshonee to aid the Louis and Clark expedition...or just in general. I don't know a good specific day, though many Indians put great value on June 21st, since most revere the Sun, and that is its longest day... Wouldn't bother me none - cuz it's my birthday - - Indians/Native Americans have had a pretty rough go of it for the last 300 years at the hands of European-types. I'd much prefer to see a little honor shown their way-ahey Wandering and Wondering

content: quote: Originally posted by pita45: i heard natives are asking for our own veterans day. not sure what i think. i'm native, and a navy retiree. and i know as a racial group, we have a much higher percentage for people joining and serving in the military than another other race. and yet, when i watch the parades, etc i never see any other natives. thoughts? I never noticed that my brothers in arms had different heritages than I did. We all bled Infantry Blue. Why would I notice now? It's not that there is no God or that He isn't listening. You're probably just asking the wrong questions.

title: native american veterans

content: My neighbor is Pauete Indian, they have a pow wow twice a year, and they always do a military salute. He was in the Marines and in Vietnam. I love that they have something separate where they honor the veterans (all veterans). They all wear full tribal clothing and share their dancing and food. I believe he is going somewhere this weekend to set up a veterans memorial. He use to live on a reservation and is highly regarded in our community along with his wife. He is a wealth of information and makes the most amazing head pieces.
reply: My neighbor is Pauete Indian, they have a pow wow twice a year, and they always do a military salute. He was in the Marines and in Vietnam. I love that they have something separate where they honor the veterans (all veterans). They all wear full tribal clothing and share their dancing and food. I believe he is going somewhere this weekend to set up a veterans memorial. He use to live on a reservation and is highly regarded in our community along with his wife. He is a wealth of information and makes the most amazing head pieces.
title: native american veterans

content: It's interesting We've got Black History Month, why not a day for Native Americans????? Personnally I think we VET's should all stand together. Can I come???? My dad's parents came down from Quebec ( provience ) in the 1920's and were awful embarrassed about Indian blood flowing thru their veins. I think of it as History of my forefathers and am proud of them. The following is just a joke ( stolen from saturday night live ) so don't get all wacked out about it. And I'd just like to say ' I am sick and tired of the man coming down on me '

content: I am reminded of the epitaph of Philip Nolan in a short story by Edward Everett Hale, A Man Without a Country. "He loved his country as no other man has loved her; but no man deserved less at her hands" It seems to fit the Indian population rather well!
reply: I am reminded of the epitaph of Philip Nolan in a short story by Edward Everett Hale, A Man Without a Country. "He loved his country as no other man has loved her; but no man deserved less at her hands" It seems to fit the Indian population rather well!

content: I have a friend on Myspace, Miss Daisy whom is a Native American. She is in the Montana Air National Guard Great Falls, Montana and United States Air Force Browning, Montana. I will send her a message and ask her to read this thread. I truly believe our Native Americans deserve to have their special day too.....
reply: I have a friend on Myspace, Miss Daisy whom is a Native American. She is in the Montana Air National Guard Great Falls, Montana and United States Air Force Browning, Montana. I will send her a message and ask her to read this thread. I truly believe our Native Americans deserve to have their special day too.....
title: native american veterans

content: I'm sorry, but all you advocates for this separated day obviously never served in a line unit. We're all equal there, and no one gets special treatment because they're this or that. So, if we do this, do we also institute... Mexican-American Veterans Day? Black Veterans Day? Female Veterans Day? Asian Veterans Day? Injured Veterans Day? Freckled Veterans Day? Gay Veterans Day? Why are you all always looking to segrate people by class? You come here and tout your anger at racism, and then, the very next thread, you want someone honored for their race. Uh, am I the only person that sees a double standard there? Don't judge me on my race or heritage except on this day, and then you can applaud me for it... Who else is entitled to a "special day?" How about we separate the combat veterans from those that didn't deploy? Or line units from REMF staff weenies? Or a national day for officers and another national day for enlisted? How about a special day just for parents? After all, don't they deserve special recognition for being both a soldier and a parent? While we're at it, how about an Army day? Oh, and a civilian DOD day! And an "I once made something for the military" inventor's day? Maybe the outstanding NCO's should have their own day? A Navy SEAL day, an Army Ranger day, a Coastie Parajumper day... For crying out loud, people, grow the hell up. We're the military. We're. As in WE ARE. There ain't no blacks or Indians or whites or Mexicans or Christians... we're a team. No one veteran is more deserving of their own little "look at meeeeeeee!" day than their brother or sister in uniform next to them. The Air Force cook is no less important than the Navy SEAL that is no less important than the Marine JAG lawyer that is no less import than the 11 bullet stopper in the Army. Keep the racism where it belongs: in the civilian sector. Veterans bleed the same color. If you can't see that, you don't deserve to wear the friggen uniform. It's not that there is no God or that He isn't listening. You're probably just asking the wrong questions.
reply: I'm sorry, but all you advocates for this separated day obviously never served in a line unit. We're all equal there, and no one gets special treatment because they're this or that. So, if we do this, do we also institute... Mexican-American Veterans Day? Black Veterans Day? Female Veterans Day? Asian Veterans Day? Injured Veterans Day? Freckled Veterans Day? Gay Veterans Day? Why are you all always looking to segrate people by class? You come here and tout your anger at racism, and then, the very next thread, you want someone honored for their race. Uh, am I the only person that sees a double standard there? Don't judge me on my race or heritage except on this day, and then you can applaud me for it... Who else is entitled to a "special day?" How about we separate the combat veterans from those that didn't deploy? Or line units from REMF staff weenies? Or a national day for officers and another national day for enlisted? How about a special day just for parents? After all, don't they deserve special recognition for being both a soldier and a parent? While we're at it, how about an Army day? Oh, and a civilian DOD day! And an "I once made something for the military" inventor's day? Maybe the outstanding NCO's should have their own day? A Navy SEAL day, an Army Ranger day, a Coastie Parajumper day... For crying out loud, people, grow the hell up. We're the military. We're. As in WE ARE. There ain't no blacks or Indians or whites or Mexicans or Christians... we're a team. No one veteran is more deserving of their own little "look at meeeeeeee!" day than their brother or sister in uniform next to them. The Air Force cook is no less important than the Navy SEAL that is no less important than the Marine JAG lawyer that is no less import than the 11 bullet stopper in the Army. Keep the racism where it belongs: in the civilian sector. Veterans bleed the same color. If you can't see that, you don't deserve to wear the friggen uniform. It's not that there is no God or that He isn't listening. You're probably just asking the wrong questions.

I will send her a message and ask her to read this thread. I truly believe our Native Americans deserve to have their special day too.....

title: native american veterans

content: I'm sorry, but all you advocates for this separated day obviously never served in a line unit. We're all equal there, and no one gets special treatment because they're this or that. So, if we do this, do we also institute... Mexican-American Veterans Day? Black Veterans Day? Female Veterans Day? Asian Veterans Day? Injured Veterans Day? Freckled Veterans Day? Gay Veterans Day? Why are you all always looking to segrate people by class? You come here and tout your anger at racism, and then, the very next thread, you want someone honored for their race. Uh, am I the only person that sees a double standard there? Don't judge me on my race or heritage except on this day, and then you can applaud me for it... Who else is entitled to a "special day?" How about we separate the combat veterans from those that didn't deploy? Or line units from REMF staff weenies? Or a national day for officers and another national day for enlisted? How about a special day just for parents? After all, don't they deserve special recognition for being both a soldier and a parent? While we're at it, how about an Army day? Oh, and a civilian DOD day! And an "I once made something for the military" inventor's day? Maybe the outstanding NCO's should have their own day? A Navy SEAL day, an Army Ranger day, a Coastie Parajumper day... For crying out loud, people, grow the hell up. We're the military. We're. As in WE ARE. There ain't no blacks or Indians or whites or Mexicans or Christians... we're a team. No one veteran is more deserving of their own little "look at meeeeeeee!" day than their brother or sister in uniform next to them. The Air Force cook is no less important than the Navy SEAL that is no less important than the Marine JAG lawyer that is no less import than the 11 bullet stopper in the Army. Keep the racism where it belongs: in the civilian sector. Veterans bleed the same color. If you can't see that, you don't deserve to wear the friggen uniform. It's not that there is no God or that He isn't listening. You're probably just asking the wrong questions.
